intro_narration.text: The cold was a venom, sinking into my bones, absolute and immediate. It wasn't just temperature; it was the cold of a million years, clinging to my skin like frostbite.
The air was a stagnant soup of ozone, metallic tang, and the cloying scent of something indefinably wrong, like old blood and electrical fire.
I tried to push myself up, but my limbs were leaden.
The darkness was a crushing weight, pressing on my eyeballs until geometric patterns of frantic red and blue light flashed behind them.
I had no name, no past, only the frantic, choking pulse of terror in my ears.
I scraped my knuckles along the wall. The sound of my own breathing was frantic and ragged.
Then, the voice—a sterile, amplified command that vibrated in the marrow of my jawbone.
"WAKE UP, %NAME%. The Sisyphus Protocol demands payment. The Fragments are your absolution."
The name %NAME% ripped a spike of pure adrenaline through me. Absolution? The ground beneath my feet shifted, gritty and sharp.
My searching hand closed on something small and worn.

fragment_1.speaker: System
fragment_1.text: Looking at the red wooden block, your mind rang in high pitch as flashes of unlcear memories appear.

fragment_1.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_1.text: I stood, momentarily blind, in a kitchen soaked in morning sun. The air was thick with the beautiful, agonizing smell of toast and cinnamon. Laughter, small and bell-like, was a knife turning in my gut.

fragment_1.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_1.text: A woman, her face a blur of light, stood at the counter.

fragment_1.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_1.text: A small, perfect hand reached up, holding the twin of the red block.

fragment_1.speaker: Child
fragment_1.text: Daddy, look! We’ll build a tower,

fragment_1.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_1.text: The child chirped, her voice vibrating with innocent joy.

fragment_1.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_1.text: The woman’s voice, a memory too precious to bear, corrected gently.

fragment_1.speaker: Woman
fragment_1.text: A is for Adam. The start of everything.

fragment_1.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_1.text: I felt a gut-wrenching ache of love and loss that was not my own. I tried to move, to shout her name, but was paralyzed.

fragment_1.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_1.text: TThen, the silence was ripped apart—a sudden, wet WRENCH of twisting metal that became a deafening, diamond-sharp PITCH of shattering glass. The sound was so massive it felt like my internal organs were rupturing.

fragment_1.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_1.text: I slammed back into the dark, screaming. The memory’s sound had left a phantom ringing, and a spike of blinding pain lanced through my temple.

fragment_1.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_1.text: I clawed at the air, dry-heaving the nonexistent cinnamon scent. Adam. A. I knew the ending of that perfect scene was the crash, and the knowledge was a poison.

fragment_1.speaker: Voice
fragment_1.text: Pathetic. Still denying the impact, Architect?

fragment_1.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_1.text: The voice was now laced with vicious contempt.

fragment_1.speaker: Voice
fragment_1.text: The truth must be faced. Seek the next fragment before the decay sets in.

fragment_1.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_1.text: I found a gap—a fissure in the wall that smelled like stagnant air and fear—and forced my body through.

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: I dragged myself into a chamber where the air was thick and moist. A single, faint pulse of blue-white light originated from a corner.

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: Crawling toward it, I found a tangled cluster of cold, heavy medals. The gold was tarnished, and the ribbon had been deliberately shredded.

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: The weight of the metal felt like an unbearable anchor in my hand.

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: As I held them, the ambient cold intensified into a deep, electric shock, and the air filled with the caustic smell of burning circuitry and antiseptic.

fragment_2.speaker: SYSTEM
fragment_2.text: Memory Flash: The Archive Room

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: I was wearing a stained lab coat. My hands shook violently as I stared at a steel gurney. A figure lay there, wrapped in metallic foil, its face visible—my own face, grey, sunken, and utterly lifeless.

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: A display console flashed a warning: SUBJECT INTEGRITY: 0.1% - CORE CASCADING FAILURE.

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: I didn't recognize the face, but the voice was my own, tight with manic despair.

fragment_2.speaker: PAST %NAME%
fragment_2.text: “I have to keep it, Elara! The guilt—it’s the only proof I was human! If I lose the guilt, I lose everything!”

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: My past self shrieked, tears blurring the text I typed on a console:

fragment_2.speaker: PAST %NAME%
fragment_2.text: “Execute full memory archive. Initiate Protocol IKP. Wipe ALL surface data. Load subject into the Perpetual Dark. Project Chimera is now SELF-CONTAINMENT.”

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: A female assistant, Elara, her face streaked with tears, slapped my arm.

fragment_2.speaker: Elara
fragment_2.text: %NAME% ! He’s gone, you’re just trapping his ghost! This is a rejection of reality! You were supposed to live!

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: My past self was laughing now, a broken, hysterical sound.

fragment_2.speaker: PAST %NAME%
fragment_2.text: No, no. I'll make sure he never gets the quiet he wanted. He will remember, forever. He will be the architect of his own hell.

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: I released the medals with a howl. The image of my own dead face on the gurney was seared onto my retina.

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: I staggered, the sudden realization that I was the Subject, the prisoner, the ghost I was fighting to forget, making me vomit bile onto the cold, gritty floor.

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: The terror was no longer abstract; it was the realization that I was living in a trap built by a smarter, more broken version of myself.

fragment_2.speaker: Voice
fragment_2.text: Good,

fragment_2.speaker: %NAME%
fragment_2.text: The voice hissed, closer now, a rasping whisper that felt like a parasite burrowing into my ear.

fragment_2.speaker: Voice
fragment_2.text: The Subject accepts his purpose. Now, find the reflection. Accept the consequence.

MIRROR_BOSS_INTRO.speaker: %NAME%
MIRROR_BOSS_INTRO.text: Blindly, I lurched toward the distant flicker of light.

MIRROR_BOSS_INTRO.speaker: %NAME%
MIRROR_BOSS_INTRO.text: The gap I had forced myself through widened into a passage, leading to a massive, echoing chamber. In the center, illuminated by cold, blue light, stood a towering, unbroken mirror.

MIRROR_BOSS_INTRO.speaker: %NAME%
MIRROR_BOSS_INTRO.text: My foot struck something—the smooth, curved edge of glass.

MIRROR_BOSS_INTRO.speaker: %NAME%
MIRROR_BOSS_INTRO.text: I lowered my hand and grasped a sliver of curved, razor-sharp mirrored glass—a fragment of a rearview mirror, lying discarded at the base of the giant reflection.

MIRROR_BOSS_INTRO.speaker: %NAME%
MIRROR_BOSS_INTRO.text: As the blood welled around the glass in my palm, the darkness, the cold, the voice, and my sanity shattered in one final, cataclysmic memory load.

ending_scene.speaker: %NAME%
ending_scene.text: The flash was not a sequence; it was a flood of pure, agonizing FEELING.

ending_scene.speaker: %NAME%
ending_scene.text: The heat of the argument. The blinding rage in the car. The sickening inertia as the vehicle left the road.

ending_scene.speaker: %NAME%
ending_scene.text: The instant the metal impacted the central concrete pillar. The sudden, absolute silence of the back seat.

ending_scene.speaker: %NAME%
ending_scene.text: I hadn't walked away untouched; I walked away alone.

ending_scene.speaker: %NAME%
ending_scene.text: I hadn't just caused the crash; I had spent the next three days in a state of psychotic breakdown, designing the Sisyphus system not to escape justice, but to escape the excruciating memory of Julie's untouched red wooden block lying beside the wreckage.

ending_scene.speaker: %NAME%
ending_scene.text: The Sisyphus Protocol was a self-sustaining torture mechanism.

ending_scene.speaker: %NAME%
ending_scene.text: The Perpetual Dark was designed for a consciousness to continuously re-learn and re-experience the guilt until it achieved Integrity.

ending_scene.speaker: %NAME%
ending_scene.text: The Voice was the recorded, digitized echo of the real %NAME% —the Architect— a spectral guardian of guilt, designed to break my amnesia (the surface identity) every time it manifested, ensuring the loop continued.

ending_scene.speaker: %NAME%
ending_scene.text: I collapsed, my body convulsing in a seizure of despair.

ending_scene.speaker: %NAME%
ending_scene.text: My scream was trapped in my throat, a silent, internal rupture. I was not just the architect of my prison; I was the maintenance man of my own damnation.

ending_scene.speaker: %NAME%
ending_scene.text: I had built this cage for my soul, and I was the only one with the key.

ending_scene.speaker: %NAME%
ending_scene.text: "I… I am the monster," I choked out, tasting bile and copper.

ending_scene.speaker: %NAME%
ending_scene.text: The voice—the IKP—was no longer synthetic. It sounded like a tired man weeping.

ending_scene.speaker: Voice
ending_scene.text: Now, you must choose to unlock it. You must accept what A is for—Absolution, or Annihilation. The true ending awaits outside the dark. But know this: every path leads back to the red block.
